Facebook publishes a blog post disputing the premise of a New York Times article that revealed that Facebook gave user data to phone device makers. (This is perhaps the first, or among the first, blog posts to dispute journalists' coverage of the company, though representatives from Facebook and other platforms have become increasingly vocal on Twitter about such matters.)
Facebook terminates its controversial Trending product (as well as its product Signal, a tool often used by journalists to find content across the platform).
The Wall Street Journal reports that Apple plans to expand its digital advertising footstep via its apps.
Papua New Guinea will temporarily shut down Facebook while officials study platform use and issues like the spread of misinformation.
Twitter will launch a website for small publishers to help them learn how to monetize on the platform.

Facebook begins requiring election-related and "issue" ads to have a "paid for by" disclosure and for buyers to verify their identity. Issues include, for example, abortions and guns. Publishers are concerned that promoted posts about political subjects will be subject to the new requirements.
Twitter creates a special label for midterm candidates' user profiles.
Recode reports that Snap will launch a media accelerator.

The Wall Street Journal reports that Google will meet with pubishers who have questions and concerns around the GDPR, including Google's decision to place upon publishers using Google ad products the responsibility of obtaining consent from users.
Facebook Stories begins testing ads.
Facebook will partner with think tank Atlantic Council, which will help the platform understand and anticipate "emerging threats and disinformation campaigns from around the world."
Google releases YouTube Music, which will stream music like Spotify, and YouTube Premium, which will offer ad-free video.
Facebook releases its first Community Standards Enforcement Report, which reveals, for example, that 583 million fake accounts were closed in Q1 of 2018 and 837 million pieces of spam.
Facebook suspends 200 apps after an investigation into data misuse.
Digiday reports that Facebook will pay publishers between $1 million and $10 million for news shows for Watch.
Facebook updates Live with features like Live Rewind for users and Live Crossposting for page managers.
Google reveals its revamped Google News at the I/O conference. New features like Newscasts and Full Coverage will provide multiple news sources for a story, and in a range of formats.
Google announces that it will start requiring political ad buyers to provide identification information to prove U.S. citizenship or lawful residency, among other details.
Bloomberg reports that Facebook is considering an ad-free subscription plan for users.
Facebook releases new metrics to allow page administrators to gain insights into video audience retention, including, for example, retention by followers vs. non-followers, and by gender.
Axios reports that Facebook has hired two external advisors (one to conduct an audit) in light of allegations regarding bias towards minority and conservative groups.

Facebook ends its Free Basics internet initiative in several regions after criticism, including on its role in facilitating hate-speech. This service provides free internet access to users through the platform.
Mark Zuckerberg announces new "Clear History" feature at the F8 conference, which will allow users to erase their Facebook browsing data.

9to5 reports on rumors that have emerged about Apple wanting to acquire Condé Nast. The publishing company's CEO Bob Sauerberg released a statement to the New York Post: “we are not for sale.” These rumors coincide with Apple's recent acquisition of the magazine subscription app Texture and plans to launch a premium news subscription product.
The Washington Post reports that WhatsApp founder and chief executive Jan Koum will step down from his role after disagreements with Facebook on encryption and user data policies.
Twitter forms new partnerships with media companies like Disney and NBCUniversal that will produce exclusive shows for the platform.

Digiday reports that Apple is pushing publishers to create longer videos for its News app after Apple created a Top Videos section to promote participating publishers. Apple is also placing ads in those videos and taking 50 percent of revenue.
Amazon renews NFL deal to stream Thursday night football games on the platform. The games will be available to its Prime subscribers and users on its gamer-focused service, Twitch.
Snapchat expands its partnership with Viacom, which will create new shows and produce Our Stories content for Snapchat.

Facebook announces, in a blogpost, that it will publish their internal enforcement guidelines to increase transparency and receive feedback. The social media platform is also developing a new feature that will allow users to request a re-review of content takedowns.

BuzzFeed reporter Alex Kantrowitz tweets that there is "no sign" of the Ad Transparency Center, six months after Twitter announced that it would launch "in the coming weeks." Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responds by tweeting: "Was definitely a mistake for us to say 'in the coming weeks.' Our fault. It’s at least months of work, and we are aiming to launch by summer. Important for us to get this right."

A CNN investigation found that ads from "hundreds" of brands and organizations, including government agencies, appeared on YouTube channels "promoting white nationalists, Nazis, pedophilia, conspiracy theories and North Korean propaganda."
Snapchat's new Shoppable AR lets advertisers link websites to sponsored photo filters. Users will be able to buy products directly within Snapchat.
Medietrends reports that Facebook says they are "likely" to roll out new buttons that will allow users to vote comments up or down.

In a blogpost, Facebook announces that its updated "terms and data policy" will rollout to everyone on the platform, not just those in the EU. These changes include allowing users to set data sharing and face recognition preferences as well as improving platform protection for teen users.

Bloomberg reports that Apple will launch a subscription service within the next year by integrating the technology of its previously acquired magazine subscription app, Texture, into its current news product, Apple News. The participating magazine publishers will receive a portion of the service's revenue.

Facebook partners with Boom, a fact-checking firm in India, to "review English-language news stories shared on the platform that are flagged by users, check facts, and rate their accuracy." This pilot test will only run in India, Facebook's largest market, coinciding with the upcoming state elections in Karnataka, India.
Digiday reports that Snapchat is testing a commerce function with some Discover partners.
Reddit finds nearly 1,000 accounts potentially linked to Russia's IRA.
Mark Zuckerberg appears before Congress for two days of testimony as fallout from the Cambridge Analytica scandal continues. He answered questions on topics ranging from the GDPR to "fake news."
Facebook partners with various foundations to launch a new initiative that will facilitate independent academic research on the impact of social media on democracy, focusing primarily on elections.

TechCrunch reports that sources told them that Facebook deleted messages sent to them by Mark Zuckerberg from their inbox. Facebook responded to TechCrunch's inquiry in a statement claiming that it took these measures to "protect our executives’ communications" and that they were done in "full compliance with our legal obligations to preserve messages".

Facebook acknowledges delay in detecting foreign interference on its site and announces plans to increase transparency on the platform. Moving forward, it will require all advertisers to provide information about their identity and location before allowing them to promote "issue ads". Issue ads, as described in the blog post, consist of ads that contain communications on "political topics that are being debated across the country". The company will also label these ads as "Political Ad" and provide users with information on who's funding the ad.

Australia plans to investigate Facebook for possible violation of privacy laws after the company revealed that approximately 300,000 users, out of the 87 million whose data Cambridge Analytica obtained, were in Australia. Authorities in Indonesia also announced their plans to initiate an investigation into the company's compliance with the country's privacy laws, according to CNN.
Recode reports on Twitter's removal of more than 1.2 million terrorism-promoting accounts on the platform, of which 274,000 were removed during the second half of 2017.
In the first audit conducted by the Media Rating Council, Facebook and Instagram receive accreditation on how they report ad impressions in the News Feed. Two additional ad audits are forthcoming.

TechCrunch reports that Cambridge Analytica released a statement refuting a Facebook report that the company "improperly" obtained the data of 87 million Facebook users. Cambridge Analytica admits to licensing data on 30 million users from Global Science Research, and claims that the data was not used to influence 2016 election outcomes.

Bloomberg reports that a Facebook white paper, published shortly after the 2016 election, highlights that "Trump’s FB campaigns were more complex than Clinton’s and better leveraged Facebook’s ability to optimize for outcomes."

Facebook updates the News Feed with features that help users better identify trustworthy sources. The feature, which was in testing last year and will now be released in the US, shows users other articles by the same publisher and allows users to see friends who shared that article.

Facebook reports that it has deleted more than 100 Facebook and Instagram accounts, as well as 138 Facebook pages, that were run by Russia's Internet Research Agency. Facebook's Chief Security Officer Alex Stamos, who published the blog post about the decision, noted the IRA's efforts to manipulate user experience on the platform while stating that "Facebook was built for conversation and human connection."
Facebook updates its Messenger capabilities to support 360 photos and HD videos. The photos can be taken directly from the app while the videos can only be shared through the app.
Snapchat launches a new video chat feature that will enable users to communicate in groups of up to 16 people.

During an interview on Vox's The Ezra Klein Show, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg discusses the company's future and its efforts to become more transparent and reliable. While commenting on the company's future, Zuckerberg says: “I wish I could solve all these issues in three months or six months, but I just think the reality is that solving some of these questions is just going to take a longer period of time.”
TechCrunch reports on Facebook's plans to build a Custom Audiences certification tool that will require marketers to provide proof of having rightfully obtained users' consent to use data.

Facebook starts fact-checking photos and videos on the platform, in addition to the news articles it previously fact-checked. In a blog post about this, Facebook reiterated plans to limit foreign interference, block fake accounts and reduce the spread of false information on the platform.

Conservative publishers criticize Facebook's algorithm change by claiming that Facebook "unfairly targeted their traffic," POLITICO reports. The social media platform announced its news feed algorithm change in January, with the aim to promote content from users' friends and family and reduce content from public pages.

Digital media company behind Cooking Panda and Opposing Views, Render Media, shuts down following Facebook's changes to its branded content guidelines and changes to the News Feed algorithm to deprioritize certain types of news.

Facebook puts a halt to its app review process to audit its platform after privacy scandal involving Cambridge Analytica. During that time, developers will not be able to launch apps or chatbots on the platform.

In light of the Cambridge Analytica revelations, Facebook announces its plans to make data settings easier to find. These changes will include a new settings menu design, a privacy shortcut menu and tools to manage data. Recode also reports on Facebook shutting down Partner Categories, which will reduce the data used on the site (including third-party data) in ad targeting.
Mark Zuckerberg decides to testify before Congress after backlash from the Cambridge Analytica scandal.
Digiday reports that Apple will allow publishers using Google's ad product DoubleClick for Publishers to serve those ads in Apple News.
Instagram will now show more timely posts and introduce a "New Posts" button so that the feed doesn't auto-refresh as users scroll.
Google's Jigsaw releases Outline, an open source project that “provides a safer way for news organizations and journalists to access the internet.”

Google announces the Google News Initiative, a $300 million commitment to formalize its efforts with publishers, which include prioritizing surfacing fact-checked and quality content for its users and contributing to efforts to increase media literacy. As part of the initiative, Google expanded access to its product Subscribe with Google, which allows users to subscribe to and access subscription content using their Google account.

YouTube removes an Atlantic video of alt-right leader Richard Spencer's speech from search results, but restored it after pushback from the Atlantic. The editor in chief said that there is a "difference between videos made by Nazis and videos about Nazis."
Facebook’s Chief Information Security Officer, Alex Stamos, resigns after internal disagreements over how much information the company should disclose about disinformation on its site.
Facebook issues an apology after users report child abuse search suggestions.

Data leak involving political data firm Cambridge Analytica and Facebook surfaces a year after the election. Under the pretense of collecting data for academic purposes, Facebook reports, a contractor to the British firm obtained user data from more than 50 million Facebook profiles that would later be used to target users and potentially influence political outcomes during the 2016 election. Facebook has hired a forensics firm to investigate Cambridge Analytica and Mark Zuckerberg has issued a statement with a timeline of the events, including details on Facebook’s plan to investigate the breach. Zuckerberg has also apologized during an interview with Recode and in multiple UK and US newspaper ads. Following a CNN interview where Zuckerberg stated that he would be "happy" to testify, bipartisan leaders of several House and Senate committees requested that he testifies.

Facebook is expanding Facebook Lite to the U.S and other developed countries. This bare-bone version of the social media platform was designed to reach users with less compatible phones and data services and was originally rolled out in a handful of countries, including Vietnam and Bangladesh.
Facebook publishes a blog post explaining why it has banned Britain First and its leaders' Facebook pages.
Twitter develops curated news timelines to deliver content during breaking news events, which it will promote via a module at the top of the home timeline.

After receiving criticisms for hosting extremist content on the site, YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki speaks on the company's plans to add "information cues" to conspiracy-related videos during a panel at the South by Southwest Interactive festival. When there is a conspiracy video, the information cue will appear below the video with a link to Wikipedia for more information.
Facebook to launch a news section, that caters strictly to national news, on its Watch platform.

Google plans to change the way paying news subscribers access stories, in an effort to support media companies. Specifically, users will see stories from publications to which they subscribe toward the top of search results. The company will make an official announcement on March 20.
Google releases a report detailing its progress on taking down deceptive content on its platforms. The firm reports removing "3.2B‘bad ads’ and blocked 320K publishers, 90K sites, 700K mobile apps".
YouTube caps the amount of time contracted moderators can spend reviewing disturbing content at four hours per day.
Recode reports that Apple has purchased digital magazine app Texture.
Google announces plans to push for the standardization of the AMP framework for non-AMP web content.
The Associated Press will work in partnership with Facebook to leverage their fact-checking capabilities during the U.S midterm election.
Facebook is working on fact-checking protocols for satirical news pieces after satirical website The Babylon Bee protested Facebook for disputing their story.
Facebook announces a pilot feature that will enable publishers to label articles and live videos as Breaking News.
Reddit CEO announces that the company is investigating Russian propaganda on the site.
Facebook ends Explore Feed pilot in response to user feedback reporting that they did not want multiple news feeds.
Digiday reports Snapchat has become increasingly flexible about advertising agreements and ad placements on its platform.

Facebook reports having found little evidence of Russian involvement in Brexit referendum, after the House of Commons committee requested that the firm investigate Russian ad spend during the period leading up to the referendum.

Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey tweets to announce Twitter's commitment to helping "increase the collective health, openness, and civility of public conversation, and to hold ourselves publicly accountable towards progress."
Twitter introduces Bookmarks feature to allow users to save tweets.
Facebook announces three-month pilot program, Local News Subscriptions Accelerator, to help publishers improve their digital subscriptions business.
Feel-good publisher LittleThings shuts down following Facebook's algorithm change in January to deprioritize news in the News Feed.

Obama speaks at an MIT conference about Google, Facebook and Twitter's influence on American culture and the need for "business models that recognizes they are a public good as well as a commercial enterprise".
Data Journalist Jonathan Albright discovers network of 9,000 conspiracy-related videos on Youtube.
Facebook Journalism Project to launch journalist training program in partnership with Society of Professional Journalists. The training will focus on Facebook's own tools and products.
White nationalist Jared Taylor and his organization, American Renaissance, sue Twitter for banning their accounts.
Facebook announces plans to bring clarity to its ad metrics, including reducing the number of metrics used and adding labels such as "estimated".
Snapchat plans to double the number of its video shows, and will do so in part by approaching more digital and legacy publishers.
Facebook removes redundant and outdated reporting metrics and introduces metric labels to simplify ad measurement.
Google will no longer support the meta news keyword tag in Google News. The feature was previously introduced to help news publishers classify their stories but was only adopted by 5% of publishers.

Vice President of Facebook Ads, Rob Goldman, apologizes to Facebook and special counsel Robert Mueller after tweeting his personal views on the recent indictment of 13 Russians for their involvement in the Trump campaign, and the use of Facebook in that effort.
Donald Trump responds to Vice President of Facebook Ads' tweet, in which he reports that "the majority of Russian Ad spend happened AFTER the election."

After noticing that Twitter had a live streaming window that aired coverage of the Florida school shooting, BuzzFeed reports that Twitter will partner with local news stations to air live footage during breaking news events.
Snapchat will give analytics to creators, likely in an effort to prevent them from moving to competing platforms like Instagram.
Google releases to all publishers its AMP stories, which is similar to Snapchat stories.
Facebook to release a new design of Page Insights that will "deliver page posts’ organic reach using the same methodology as it has for promoted posts".

Also at the Code Media conference, Facebook announced it would add a news section to Watch that could be useful in breaking news, and that it had resolved issues with Apple that prevented Facebook from rolling out subscriptions for publishers in its app on iOS devices.

At the Code Media conference, Facebook's head of news partnerships said, "If you're a publisher who feels Facebook isn't good for your business, you shouldn't be on Facebook," adding, "News organizations should be thinking differently about their relationship with Facebook. This is not us stepping back from news, this is us changing our relationship with publishers. This is about Facebook doing something it's never done before, having a point of view and leaning into quality news."
Recode reports that Snapchat is offering free ad credits to advertisers to pull them away from Instagram.
Twitter reports Q4 2017 earnings and is profitable for the first time since launch.
Snapchat says that Discover partners earned $100 million in revenue in 2017.
CNBC reports that Facebook wants Watch to rival YouTube by expanding access to more creators and potentially pursuing ad rev share with some creators instead of paying directly for content.
Amazon's "other revenue," which is mostly advertising, grew more than 60 percent year-over-year in the last quarter of 2017.
The number of daily active users on Facebook fell for the first time in the U.S. and Canada.
Google brings back Featured Snippets at the top of search results, which had been criticized for surfacing false information from unreliable sources, and statements like "women are evil."
Facebook announces that the News Feed will "prioritize local news."
Facebook announces the Facebook Journalism Project Scholarship for students.
Google begins testing a hyperlocal news app called Bulletin to which any user can contribute.
Bloomberg reports that Twitter is working on a video sharing feature that is similar to Snapchat.
Google will allow users to mute certain ads. For example, the reminder ads that show a product that a user had been searching for on another site.
Twitter will allow for advertiser sponsored Moments.
Snapchat will allow users to share public Stories outside of the app, across the web.

Twitter will contact the 677,775 users who interacted with accounts with potential connections to Russia, according to a company blog post providing updates about the company's investigation into Russia-related election meddling.
Facebook will allow users to rate which news sites they find "trustworthy," and those entities will be priotitized in the News Feed.
Digiday reports that Snapchat will host a publisher summit, and sent a note to publishers doubling down on the relationship.
Cheddar reports that Snap laid off two dozen employees that were on a publisher partnerships team.

Recode reports that Twitter's director of public policy told senators that the company is “working to identify and inform individually the users who have been exposed to IRA accounts during the election."
Google announces that, beginning in July 2018, faster pages will rank (and surface) higher in mobile search.
Facebook updates the News Feed to prioritize user content over publishers', which is expected to result in a significantly smaller audience and less revenue for publishers.
Facebook is testing a feature called Today In that will highlight local news and events

In response to controversy after a famous YouTube creator decided to post a video of a person who had committed suicide, YouTube's account on Twitter wrote an open letter that read, "We know that the actions of one creator can affect the entire community, so we’ll have more to share soon on steps we’re taking to ensure a video like this is never circulated again."
Google will remove the "google.com/amp" from AMP post URLs, at the end of which a publisher's URL was attached. Posts now appear under a publisher's URL.
The Internet Association, which includes companies like Google and Facebook, will fight against the FCC's repeal of net neutrality.

Twitter publishes a post called "World Leaders on Twitter" that read (likely in response to pressure to delete Trump's account, but broad in scope): "Blocking a world leader from Twitter or removing their controversial Tweets would hide important information people should be able to see and debate."
Social Pro Daily reports that Facebook is testing a feature that would allow brands to send mass messages on Messenger.

Facebook and Universal Music agree to a music licensing deal that will allow users to upload videos with licensed music. (Related: two weeks later, YouTube announces it will release a music subscription service.)
Germany's Federal Cartel Office finds that, as a result of its market dominance, Facebook leaves users with little choice but to accept their questionable data collection practices.
Digiday reports that Facebook wants to change the terms around Watch videos in ways that would limit monetization opportunities for publishers.
Facebook will show Related Articles instead of a Disputed Flag next to stories flagged as false.

Publishers will have to pay to participate in the Coalition for Better Ads' Better Ads Experience Program (Google is a founding member), in which they pledge not to run "annoying ads." Participating and non-participating publishers will face potential site take-down if they do so.
Facebook will fight "engagement bait" in the News Feed.
Google will no longer allow sites that don't disclose their country of origin to appear in Google News.

Twitter pauses account verification and tweets: "Verification was meant to authenticate identity & voice but it is interpreted as an endorsement or an indicator of importance. We recognize that we have created this confusion and need to resolve it."
Recode reports that Apple released a new feature in iTunes called Podcast Analytics for podcast creators an advertisers.
Facebook will allow pre-roll ads for Watch videos.
Digiday reports that Facebook will no longer pay publishers to produce Live videos for the News Feed.
CNN reports that Instagram is testing a standalone messaging app in Turkey, Uruguay, Chile, Portugal, Italy and Israel.
Google removes access to YouTube from all Amazon streaming devices, following an earlier move to remove YouTube from Echo. Amazon also refuses to make Amazon Prime available on Google devices.

YouTube CEO publishes a blog post on "Expanding our work against abuse of our platform," which includes adding human content reviewers and increasing transparency around content guidelines, among other efforts.
Facebook introduces an app called Messenger Kids.
Twitter expands availability of Twitter Lite, which uses less data, to 24 additional countries.
YouTube begins testing a feature called Reels, which is similar to Stories on Facebook and Snapchat.
Recode reports that Facebook will allow some publishers to label some stories as "breaking."
Facebook and Twitter will cooperate with UK officials investigating potential Russian involvement with Brexit vote.
Facebook teams up with Toronto's Ryerson School of Journalism for a "digital news innovation challenge" to combat misinformation.
The Next Web finds that Instagram is quietly testing new features, including a regram button and GIF search, among others.

Facebook's VP of ad products wrote a blog post called "Our Advertising Principles," which tells users that the platform doesn't sell "personal information" like name, phone number, or email address, and tells users how they can "control" the ads they're shown.
Snapchat releases Promoted Stories for advertisers.
Facebook will create a portal so users can see if they liked any accounts on FB or Instagram linked to Russia's Internet Research Agency.
Facebook begins testing Trust Indicators, created in collaboration with the Trust Project, to better identify trustworthy publishers.
Google moves to prevent publishers from posting stories to AMP that require readers to click through to read the full version.
TechCrunch confirms that Twitter is testing a "tweetstorm" feature.

Twitter updated their system for reviewing reports of abusive, violent, or hateful content, and also updated rules so that handles, bios, and user and header photos are taken into consideration, as well as affiliation with organizations (even off platform) that promote violence.
Instagram begins testing a feature to allow users to follow hashtags.
Google will start to show more information about publishers in search results so users can "understand the tone, expertise and history of the publisher."

During a call about the company's quarterly earnings report, which was disappointing, Evan Spiegel said Snapchat would start to pay creators on the platform, and that the app will be redesigned to become easier to use.
Twitter expands character limit for tweets to 280.
Facebook adds a "Monetization Tab" to Instant Articles to allow publishers to easily turn on or off Recirculation Ads, which appear at the bottom of the articles.

On the heels of US congresssional hearings with Facebook, Google, and Twitter regarding Russia and the US election, UK lawmakers asked Twitter to give them a list of accounts linked to the Russian government backed Internet Research Agency.

Facebook's quarterly earnings report came out at the same time as the congressional hearings, showing growth. Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement to investors, "We're serious about preventing abuse on our platforms. We're investing so much in security that it will impact our profitability," adding, "Protecting our community is more important than maximizing our profits."
The House Intelligence Committee released some of the ads linked to Russia and purchased on Facebook before the election.

Recode reported on early testimony from Facebook, Google, and Twitter in preparation for Congressional hearings later in the week. Facebook planned to reveal that 126 million Facebook users may have seen Russian-government backed content, and that some of that content was also on Instagram; Google would discuss results from an internal investigation that found "evidence of efforts to misuse our platforms during the 2016 U.S. election by actors linked to the Internet Research Agency in Russia," and Twitter would reveal that 2,700 accounts on its own platform were linked to that agency.

Google announced, "We have found some evidence of efforts to misuse our platforms during the 2016 U.S. election by actors linked to the Internet Research Agency in Russia." The company plans to create a public database of its ads and to require political advertisers to be based in the U.S.

Facebook announces move toward requiring all political advertisers to verify their identity, and to increase transparency around all ads by allowing users to see things like dollars spent, impressions, and target demographics.
Twitter will label political ads on its platform, and increase transparency around the ads on the platform and who paid for them.
Twitter said that it over counted monthly user numbers for three years.
Twitter will no longer accept ads from Russia Today (RT) and Sputnik because of their efforts to interfere with the election.
Facebook releases News Feed Publisher Guidelines that encourages meaningful, informative, accurate, and authentic posts.
Digiday reports that Snapchat will increase programmatic ads for shows and has struggled to fill those ad slots.
The Information reports that Snap overestimated demand for Spectacles, and many units remain unused.
In six countries, Facebook tests a separate feed for non-promoted posts, causing publisher traffic to fall.
The Information reports that LinkedIn CEO said he would consider working with publishers to develop original video content.
TechCrunch reports on tests of a new Facebook product called Sets that is similar to Pinterest's boards.
Facebook releases more information about forthcoming test of support for subscriptions in Instant Articles.
Recode reports that after a dispute over getting a cut of the revenue, Apple will block Facebook's subscription paywall on iOS.
Head of Facebook Messenger says that Facebook should "overthink" its future ad products to prevent to prevent the type of election meddling that happened in 2016.
Bloomberg reports that Facebook and Google directly helped Secure America Now's efforts to target anti-refugee ads in swing states leading up to the 2016 election.
The New York Times reports that Google allows ads containing fake news to appear even on fact-checking sites.
After founder Jack Dorsey takes to Twitter to emphasize plans to combat hate and harrassment on the platform, the Trust & Safety Council sent an email to members with new rules.
Twitter releases the Video Website Card to allow for more formats for video ads.
Facebook aquires the app tbh in an effort to reach younger audiences.
Hollywood Reporter reports that Snapchat and NBCUniversal partner to produce original shows.
Bloomberg reports that Facebook wants to hire people who have national security clearances.
AdAge reports that Facebook is testing allowing brands to study user posts to better focus their strategies.
TechCrunch reports that Facebook Stories will be open to Pages.
Reddit and Time magazine form an editorial partnership.
The House Intelligence Committee will release Facebook ads linked to Russia.
BuzzFeed reports that a Facebook executive told fact checking partners that its fake news tag reduces the spread of such posts by 80 percent.
Twitter to release a bookmarking tool to allow for saving tweets to read later.
The Washington Post reports that Google was used by Russians to purchase election-related ads.
Axios reports that Facebook has sent out an email assuring advertisers that there will be increased "human review" of ads targeted on the platform.
Quartz reports that Facebook will team up with conservative magazine the Weekly Standard as a fact-checking partner.

Facebook will roll out a button in the News Feed that will allow readers to find additional information and context for stories they read; the product was developed as part of the Facebook Journalism Project.
CNN reports that, in response to conspiracy videos about the Las Vegas shooting, YouTube has updated its algorithm to in favor of reputable news sources.
Recode reports that Google is paying publishers to use a forthcoming product called Stamp, which will compete with Snapchat Discover and Instagram Stories.
CNN reports that Russian ads on Facebook targeted two states significant to Donald Trump's victory, Wisconsin and Michigan.
TechCrunch reports that Instagram Stories can be cross-posted as Facebook Stories, but not the other way around (yet).
Vox properties, The Verge and Polygon, announce forthcoming weekly live Twitter shows.
Instagram Stories adds an interactive poll sticker that allows users to ask questions of their followers.
Fast Company reports that a post with misinformation from a blog called "Alt-Right News" during the Las Vegas shooting became a top story on Facebook's Safety Check page.

AdAge reports that Apple News is working with Google and select publishers on a trial that allows them to place ads into their Apple News pages using Google's DoubleClick ad program, which many publishers use to place ads elsewhere.

The New York Times reports on the names of pages found to have been linked to Russia, including Secured Borders, LGBT United, and Defend the 2nd. Facebook found hundreds of such pages, but hasn't publicly released the names.

Facebook releases Russian ads to Congress, estimates 10 million people in the U.S. saw the ads, and outlines efforts to increase transparency going forward, including hiring 1,000 people for their global ads review team.

Recode reports that Facebook shared data with Google to aid in Google's efforts to understand election-related activity by Russians on its own sites. Recode also reports that Google will also have a private briefing with lawmakers on the matter.

TheStreet reports that the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and Financial Times will take a wait-and-see approach to Facebook's recently launched subscription program, while other publications, like the Washington Post will.

Twitter publishes "Update: Russian Interference in 2016 US Election, Bots, & Misinformation," a roundup of findings related to their investigation of how their platform was misused, and preventative measures and changes the platform will take in light of these revelations.

Following an event at the UN the previous week, during which world leaders said that social platforms need to do more to curb terrorist activity on their platforms, the European Commission proposed new guidelines for platforms to step up their efforts in the coming months.

CNN reports that an account called Blacktivist on Facebook and Twitter was tied to the Russian govenrment and used to amplify racial tensions leading up to the U.S. presidential election. Both accounts were handed over to Congress.
AlterNet reports that Google's algorithm changes to fight misinformation have cost the site 40 percent of its traffic.

Mark Zuckerberg responds to Trump's tweets suggesting that Facebook is against him, writing on Facebook: "Trump says Facebook is against him. Liberals say we helped Trump. Both sides are upset about ideas and content they don't like. That's what running a platform for all ideas looks like."
The Hill reports that Google, Facebook, and Twitter have been invited to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee regarding election-related Russian activity on their platforms.
The Daily Beast reports on a Facebook account tied to Russia called United Muslims of America that bought election-related ads.

Facebook releases an "update on Facebook’s efforts to help defend the integrity of the elections" in Germany, in response to conerns arising around "foriegn interference" in U.S. and French elections. These include: removing fake accounts, working with government election officials, and working with media partners.
Instagram rolls out a Comment Controls feature for accounts to prevent against trolling.
Google removes YouTube videos from Amazon's Echo Show, seen as a competitive move.
Twitter doubles character limit for tweets to 280.
After deciding to leave up a tweet from Donald Trump that threatened North Korea, saying it had "newsworthiness," Twitter will update their takedown policies to make them clearer.
The Washington Post reports that, just after the election, Barack Obama spoke with Mark Zuckerberg about the importance of addressing political misinformation on the platform.

Mark Zuckerberg posts a Facebook Live video about steps the company will take to prevent election meddling, such as increased transparency around ad buys, and says the company will give Congress the ads purchased on the platforms by Russians before the election. After, Democratic Senators Amy Klobuchar and Mark Warner called for legislation to increase online political ads.

At an event at the United Nations General Assembly, British Prime Minister Theresa May and other world leaders said that social platforms need to do more to curb terrorist activity on their platforms, speaking to Google’s vice president and general counsel, who represented the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism.
Wired reports that Twitter will meet with the Senate Intelligence Committee regarding election interference by Russia, and about bots and misinformation on the platform.

Sheryl Sandberg writes a Facebook post in response to ProPublica's discovery that ads on the platform can be targeted to, for example, a "Jew-hater." As a result, Facebook will restrict the types of ad targeting that can take place, will add more human oversight of the ad targeting process, and will encourage users to report abuse.

The Globe and Mail reports that, in response to government pressure, Google and Facebook will launch campaigns to educate Canadians about misinformation, and Facebook will launch the Canadian Election Integrity Initiative.

The 11th biannual Twitter Transparency Report is released and includes more transparency around how the company handles government terms of service requests and content takedown requests, among other changes.
The Daily Beast reports on activists' complaints that Facebook has been removing posts about ethnic cleansing involving the Rohingya people in Burma.
Snapchat removed Al Jazeera from Discover in Saudi Arabia after a request from the Saudi Arabian government.
In response to a Daily Beast article that found ads can be targeted to racist users, Twitter says it fixed a bug that allowed such campaigns.
Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook gave copies of ads purchased by Russians, and additional information, to Robert Mueller as part of his investigation into Russia's influence in the election.
In January 2018, Google Chrome will only allow autoplay videos that are muted by default, or if a user has "indicated an interest."
Google introduces Community Updates, which is a redesign of Google News so that a Local tab will provide search results from local news sources.
Facebook updates ad targeting guidelines after ProPublica finds that ads can be targeted to "Jew haters," among other problematic categories.
Facebook will no longer allow advertisers to modify news article headlines.

Facebook creates content "monetization eligibility standards" so that certain content and content creators cannot make money on the platform, for example, violent, adult, or anything that is "incendiary, inflammatory, demeaning or disparages people, groups, or causes."
Google will end its "first click free" program, which gave readers some access to news sites with paywalls; publishers hope this move by Google will increase subscriptions.
TechCrunch reports that Facebook has removed Instant Articles from Messenger.
Digiday reports that Apple is testing a featured video section for Apple News; the videos are selected by editors, not algorithms.
The Spanish Data Protection Agency fines Facebook 1.2 million euros for violating user privacy.
Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook is willing to spend up to $1 billion on original video content.
Google creates a Google Analytics cookie so that changes coming to Apple's Safari browser, which would enhance user privacy by reducing data collection, will not affect AdWords campaign performance.
Business Insider reports that Instagram is testing cross-posting Stories to Facebook.
Facebook criticized for claiming to be able to reach more young Americans with ads than are listed in the U.S. census.

Facebook reports that it found $100,000 in ad spending connected to Russia, briefs lawmakers investigating election meddling. There were 470 accounts linked to the Internet Research Agency, which is known as a Russian "troll farm."
Bloomberg reports that Facebook will pay record labels and other music publishers for rights so that user videos aren't taken down for infringement.
WhatsApp will begin to charge companies for certain features, for example, one that would allow them to communicate with customers through the app.
Publisher-produced shows begin to roll out on Facebook Watch.
Snapchat VP of content tells BBC that the company conducts fact-checking of some Snaps during major events like Charlottesville.
Facebook will remove ads from pages that repeatedly share false news.
Snap Maps, which users initially found to be creepy as it shows friends' physical location, proves useful in Hurricane Harvey rescue efforts.
Wall Street Journal reports that Google will refund advertisers for ads run on sites with false traffic.
Business Insider reports that Snapchat is increasingly verifying influencers and expanding its Official Stories in order to stay competitive with Instagram Stories.
Facebook hires former New York Times public editor Liz Spayd to oversee a companywide transparency effort.

Google begins a widespread crackdown on extremist content, pulling ads and adding warnings to content that doesn't formally violate community guidelines and therefore cannot be taken down. The effort was announced in June.
At an event, Facebook's chief security officer says the platform takes down more than 1 million accounts each day.

Business Insider reports that Facebook's former VP of ads and business platforms, who also oversaw the early rollout of the News Feed and Messenger, will lead their hardware efforts, including wearables, VR, and a product that will compete with Amazon's Echo.
Facebook will live stream 15 college football games on it's new Watch page.
Snapchat executive says the company will have scripted video by the end of the year.

Mark Zuckerberg writes a Facebook post about efforts to support publishers through the Facebook Journalism project, including adding publisher logos and not taking a cut of subscription revenue publishers earn through the platform.
When launched in the fall, iOS11 will change Google's AMP links back to links to the original article when shared or copied.
Any user will be able to upload video to the site using LinkedIn's app.
Facebook adds publisher logos to Trending and Search so readers can more easily identify news sources and brands.
Google begins testing tools to accomodate subscription-supported publications.
Axios reports that the daily Snapchat Discover show, Stay Tuned, hits 29 million unique viewers.
Facebook updates the News Feed to eliminate "video clickbait," which includes fake play buttons and video of a standalone image

Facebook will allow advertisers to buy ads that will only appear in videos, not also as a standalone ad in the News Feed, allowing it to compete with other video services, like YouTube, that offer the option.
Fast Company reports that Amazon Echo Show is staying away from serious news stories, such as the events in Charlottesville.
Business Insider reports that Facebook shut down an internal online group as political conversations, particularly around Trump, became heated.

Wall Street Journal reports that Apple budgets $1 billion for original video programming. (A few days later, New York Times reports that Facebook is willing to spend $3 to 4 million per episode of original programming, and Google $2 to 3 million.)
TechCrunch reports that Facebook will roll out a Trending News section, accessible via the mobile app's main navigation.
Facebook releases a version of its Moments app called Colorful Balloons in order to be allowed into China.
Facebook launches a tab called Watch for its original video content.
Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook stalks potentially competitive apps.

Google releases its first Ad Experience Report that ranks publishers based on their ad quality, and lets them know what might not make it through the ad quality filter that will be in the forthcoming Chrome brower.
TechCrunch reports that Facebook will no longer charge advertisers for accidental clicks.
Six years after removing their app from Apple's store over revenue share disagreements, the Financial Times will restore its app to the store, but doesn’t allow users to subscribe using it.
Recode reports that Facebook is testing putting local politicians' posts into News Feeds of users who may or may not follow that politician.
Wall Street Journal reports that Google is creating a product for publishers similar to Snapchat Discover.
Facebook updates the News Feed to prioritize articles that load faster on mobile.
Business Insider reports that Snapchat is asking college newspapers to create campus editions for Discover.
Guardian reports that Google is testing autoplay videos in search results.
TechCrunch reports on increased activity in Twitter users' Notifications tab, including trends and accounts that a user might not want to miss.
Business Insider reports that Google is running tests with publishers to detect ad fraud as part of an initiative called ads.txt.
Twitter updates reporters on anti-abuse strategy, and says the efforts are working.
Facebook releases highlights from the first six months of the Facebook Journalism Project.
Facebook releases a tool to allow publishers to compare performance of Instant versus mobile web articles.
Snapchat and NBC will create a news show called Stay Tuned.
Snapchat released a tool called Snap Publisher to allow any photo or video to be converted into a vertical video ad.
Snapchat’s ad team starts selling against Discover.
Digiday reports that Facebook is moving forward with plans to test paid subscriptions to publications through Instant Articles.
Google adds mobile-friendly native ad formats for publishers to place in their feeds or within articles.
Google funds The Press Association to create a robot reporter to write 30,000 local news stories each month.
TechCrunch reports that Snapchat will for the first time allow links, a longstanding request from publishers.

AdAge reports that Apple News may allow publishers to use the same ad tech used to deliver ads on their sites to deliver ads to Apple News, reducing the additional workflow and potentially increasing revenue for publishers.
Digiday reports that several publishers, including CNN, CNBC, Bloomberg, Scripps and Time Inc., will create content for the Amazon Echo Show, a video and audio device released the previous month.
Facebook updates the News Feed algorithm to reduce the distribution of content by individuals who post more than 50 times a day, as those posts are usually spam or fake information.
The Washington Post reports that Twitter is seeking tools to allow users to flag misleading or harmful content.
Facebook eliminates the ability for publishers to edit link previews, such as the headline, the description, and the images, because often that ability allowed for the spread of misinformation.
Google News is redesigned on desktop to highlight fact checking.
Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter and YouTube form Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism.
Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook is talking to Hollywood studios for original scripted content .
Mashable reports that Facebook will create a standalone app for Live video creators.
Mark Zuckerberg tells CNN he's updated Facebook's mission statement, now "To give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together," in part through Facebook Groups.
Apple News will give publishers demographic metrics and will allow additional banner ad formats.
Time Warner agrees to create 10 original shows for Snapchat per year for 2 years, a $100 million deal.
Facebook will use artificial intelligence to combat terrorist content.
Facebook launches the Hard Questions initiative to open dialogue about the role of the platform in the information ecosystem.
Instagram releases a "paid partnership with" tag to provide transparency around content types.
New Facebook tools will allow advertisers to use their data to target high-spending users likely to buy certain products.
Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook is building a tool to allow users to pay and subscribe to publications.
Facebook to allow publishers to place ads in the related articles section at the base of Instant Articles.
Facebook releases tools to allow elected officials directly reach consituents.
Google launches a youth news literacy program.
Facebook Live will accomodate closed captioning.
Axios reports that iOS 11 will not have integration with Facebook and Twitter, as it has since 2012 and 2011, respectively.
Recode reports on data that found people spend 35% more time with Google AMP pages than regular mobile pages.
Financial Times reports that Facebook's shareholders will push Mark Zuckerberg on his plans to address fake news.
Politico reports that Apple News hired its first editor-in-chief.
Facebook Instant Articles platform extension will support content creation formatted for Google AMP and Apple News.
Reuters reports that Facebook is making deals with publishers for original video shows.
Audience Direct beta will allow publishers to use Facebook demographic and location data to target video ads.
Twitter hires a head of Live video content, a new position, who formerly worked at Bloomberg.
The Guardian obtains Facebook's moderation guidelines that govern how the platform deals with such issues as sexual and violent content.
Google announces that AMP is loading mobile pages 2x faster, will expand to include more ad formats.
Twitter announces an update to its policies so that a user's browsing data collected off of Twitter can be kept for up to 30 days; to take effect one month after announcement.
Facebook News Feed updated to reduce clickbait headlines.
TechCrunch reports that Instagram has begun to test location-based Stories, similar to Snapchat's.
Facebook is sanctioned by CNIL, a French data protection watchdog, for breaching the French Data Protection Act.
Facebook announces a bug that wrongly charged advertisers and "misattributed some clicks on video carousel ads as link clicks."
TechCrunch reports that Facebook will update the Live API Facebook Platform Policy to halt fake Live videos.
Facebook News Feed updated to show fewer links to low-quality web pages.
After Facebook crackdown on fake accounts caused a significant drop for USA Today, USA Today's parent company called for a FBI investigation.
YouTube announces seven shows, including with Katy Perry and Ellen DeGeneres.
CNBC reports on Facebook effort to hire a film producer.
Facebook will hire thousands of people to watch review video on the platform, in response to violent events streamed using Live.
Twitter announces nearly a dozen new shows, including with Bloomberg, The Verge, and Live Nation among others.
Alex Hardiman tapped to lead Facebook news products team.
The Australian obtained documents that show FB Australia promoted ads that exploited teens' emotions.
Facebook announces effort against government "information operations."
Facebook partners with the Knight Foundation to bring support and training to local newsrooms.
Snapchat launches in Germany, partners include Vice and Sky Sports.
Facebook begins to show related stories and fact checks before a user clicks on a story link.
The Information reports on forthcoming content discovery developments, including the ability to search for stories or videos by topic.
Google launches Project Owl to further combat "fake news."
BuzzFeed reports that Twitter plans to broadcast live video 24 hours a day.
Amazon launches "Subscribe with Amazon" for readers to access subscription publications; publishers get a 70 percent cut the first year, and 85 percent for renewals, similar to Apple News.
Recode reports that Facebook will give publishers money for produced videos, similar to its effort around Live.
Digiday reports that Guardian pulls out of Instant Articles, following in the steps of the New York Times, and Apple News.
YouTube will provide workshops to teens for spotting fake news.
Wall Street Journal reports that Google will add an ad-blocking feature for Chrome.
Facebook responds to live video of murder on its platform; later that month a man killed himself live.
Adweek reports that Snap and Conde Nast strike a deal for three channels: GQ, Wired, Self.
Facebook ramps up efforts to shut down fake accounts, leading to a drop in activity for publishers.
Bloomberg reports that Facebook put ads in German newspapers that tell readers how to spot fake news, in response to government pressure on Facebook to do more about the problem.
"Snap to Store" will let advertisers see if users visited a business after seeing a location-based ad.
Facebook gives publishers ability to do email sign ups and other ways of more directly reaching readers.
Google begins to show fact checks of search results.
Facebook offers marketers more data and ad transparency.
Facebook offers select users a guide called "Tips for spotting false news."
YouTube says no revenue for creators until they hit 10,000 views in an effort to differentiate "creators who are playing by the rules."
YouTube will bring in watchdogs to help with effort to ensure ads aren't up against terrorist, hate, or sexual content, which had prompted companies to pull ads.
Amazon wins against other platforms in bid to live stream NFL games.
Facebook joins the News Integrity Initiative to address trust in news.
Facebook adds Stories to mobile app; also tests a second news feed called Explore.
Platform adds a blur and warning of "sensitive content" over posts that users flag, but that don't warrant a takedown.
Recode reports that multiple platforms bid for NFL live-streaming rights.
The platform unveils a trending topics section, like Facebook.
Google expands marketer control over ads after they began to show up next to offensive content.
Twitter reports that it deleted more than 600k terrorism accounts from mid-2015 through 2016.
Twitter opens its live-streaming API to publishers.
Ad group ANA calls for audit of ad campaigns on these platforms.
A study by the University of Southern California finds that 48 million Twitter accounts are bots.
Largest search engines in Asia Pacific will support AMP pages.
Facebook releases its "disputed news" tag.
Facebook to prioritise “reactions” over likes in the newsfeed.
Google launches a tool to help newsrooms monitor comments.
Mid-roll video ads begin on Facebook, following an announcement in January.
Facebook allows users to send photos and videos from the in-app camera.
Facebook invites media companies to its offices to talk about products to come throughout the year.
Mark Zuckerberg writes a nearly 6,000 word manifesto, "Building Global Community," on the future of Facebook and global civil society.
Google pulls two anti-Semitic sites off its ad platform.
Autoplay videos on Facebook will play with sound.
Facebook announces an app for Apple TV and Amazon Fire that will allow people to watch Facebook videos on their TVs.
TechCrunch reports that Twitter will reduce its support for ad products that are not drawing advertisers.
The Washington Post joins Snapchat Discover as Discover shifts to allow for breaking news.
Facebook further pushes for transparency around ads and says it will allow for a third-party audit.
News surfaces that French publishers complain of effort required for anti-fake news partnership with Facebook.

Twitter continues efforts to combat harassment and improve quality, by "stopping the creation of new abusive accounts, bringing forward safer search results, and collapsing potentially abusive or low-quality Tweets."
News surfaces that a Syrian refugee identified as a terrorist pursues legal action against Facebook on grounds of "fake news."
Google allows for AMP articles URL to indicate the publisher’s name and not just Google.
Snapchat IPO documents show that media partners were paid $58 million, and that Snap-sold ad revenue was 91 percent.
Facebook investors file a resolution asking the company for a report about the impact of fake news on the platform.
Instagram introduces Albums feature in limited release. Widespread release later in the month.

Facebook updates the algorithm to prioritize "authentic" content and will surface posts around real-time/breaking news. Facebook also announces new and expanded partnerships with Nielsen, ComScore, DoubleVerify (for a total of 24 third-party entities) to give better insights into performance of ads.
Snapchat announces IPO.
Twitter’s VP of engineering announces an effort to combat harassment.
Facebook’s News Feed algorithm will reward publishers/videos that keep people watching and mid-roll ads won’t play until 90 seconds.
Recode reports that more than 200 publishers have been banned from Google’s AdSense network in an effort to combat fake news.

News that Facebook begins testing Stories, like those on Instagram and Snapchat, at the top of the mobile app in Ireland. Facebook also updates Trending to show publisher names, identify trends by number of publishers and not engagement on a single post, and show everyone in a region the same content. In Thailand and Australia, Facebook will have ads like the ones that are in News Feed inside of Messenger.
Snapchat updates publisher guidelines: content must be fact checked and cannot be risqué, and will offer some an "age gate" and will require graphic content warnings.
Snapchat will allow ad targeting using third-party data.
News that Facebook will end Live video deals with publishers in favor of longer more premium video.
Snapchat releases a universal search bar.
Instagram Stories will now have ads, and insights are increased, as the platform hits 150 million users.

Facebook announces the Facebook Journalism Project, to work with publishers on product rollouts, storytelling formats, promotion of local news, subscription models, training journalists, and, on the fake news front, collaborating with the News Literacy Project and fact checking organizations. On the same day, TechCrunch reports Facebook agrees to censor content in Thailand at government’s request.
Recode reports that Facebook will allow mid-roll video ads, with 55 percent of revenue going to publishers.

Mark Zuckerberg writes a blog post announcing that his "personal challenge" for 2018 will be to fix issues with Facebook, "whether it's protecting our community from abuse and hate, defending against interference by nation states, or making sure that time spent on Facebook is time well spent." He also wants to make sure that the platform is "a decentralizing force that puts more power in people's hands."
At the request of authorities, Apple removes the New York Times app from the Chinese App Store.
In the iOS 11.2.5 beta, Siri plays a news podcast when asked about the news. It defaults to the Washington Post, but can be changed.
Business Insider reports that Twitter inadvertently inflated video ad metrics.
Facebook launches Live Audio. Allows for formats like news radio.
Facebook begins talks with video producers and TV studios for original content.
Facebook launches Live 360 video. Users can have a spherical view of live video.
Google updates its search bar so that there is no longer an autocomplete that reads "are Jews evil."
In an effort to combat misinformation, Facebook prompts users to report "misleading language."
Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter, and YouTube partner to address terrorism content online.
To be allowed into China, Facebook built a censorship tool into its platform.
In response to post-election pressure, Mark Zuckerberg addresses Facebook’s role in fake news.
Facebook will work with more third parties to ensure the integrity of their metrics after they miscounted publisher performance.
Vertical ads are allowed on Instagram.
Facebook buys CrowdTangle, which is used by publishers for analytics.

After controversy, Facebook will curb ethnic affinity marketing by advertisers focused on, for example, credit or housing, who target users based on whether Facebook has determined they are likely Latino or Asian American, for example.
Facebook rolls out a voting planner for users where they can view and save the initiatives and candidates they will select.
Facebook allows 360 photo and video within Instant Articles.
Snapchat switches from a revenue sharing arrangement with publishers on Discover to an up-front licensing arrangement.
Signal, for news gathering on Facebook, will include a Live Video column
Facebook also allows for additional ad formats for publishers in Instant Articles.
Updates to Google AMP so it better supports a variety of ad sizes.
Twitter opens Moments to everyone.
Facebook blocks the accounts of Palestinian journalists, says it was "accidental."
Snapchat announces Spectacles and becomes Snap, Inc.
All Google search results, not just the carousel, now show AMP pages.

Improvements are made to call to action button on Instagram ads to make them more visible; with video, though, the destination URL opens first within Instagram with the video continuing to play at the top.
Publishers can sell subscriptions within the Apple News app; Apple keeps 30 percent of subscriptions made through the app, and 15 percent of renewals.
Twitter announces a live streaming partnership with Cheddar.
Facebook removes Pulitzer-winning photograph of Napalm girl and bans journalist who posted it.
Google releases a study of more than 10,000 mobile domains showing that speed matters for engagement and revenue.
Snapchat axes Local Stories.
Apple changes its Spotlight feature so that articles open in-app, hurting publishers.
Facebook Trending becomes fully algorithmically driven.
Facebook’s News Feed is modified to place emphasis on "personally informative" items.
Facebook blocks ad blockers.
Facebook tweaks the News Feed to reduce clickbait.
Instagram Stories launches. A compilation of updates a user’s friends see; a Snapchat Stories clone.
Google announces AMP for ads, to bring ads to the same load time as AMP articles.
Facebook Instant Articles can be posted to Messenger.
Twitter announces multiple live video deals, including with CBS, Wimbledon, and Bloomberg.
Snapchat introduces Memories.
Facebook’s algorithm changes to place further emphasis on family and friends and on creating a feed that will "inform" and "entertain."
Twitter Engage launches, allowing for better insights and data. Also, the length of user video is increased from 30 to 140 seconds.
Snapchat announces an online magazine called Real Life.
Facebook launches 360 photo. Users can move their phones for a spherical view within a photo.
Google announces preliminary results from AMP showing that 80 percent of publishers are seeing higher viewability and 90 percent are seeing higher engagement.
Intel becomes the first brand to publish content directly to Instant Articles.
Google AMP launches in France, Germany, Italy, UK, Russia, and Mexico.
Facebook Notify is shut down.
Facebook allows for their Audience Network to be used for ads to be seen off-Facebook, a move seen as competitive with Google.
Facebook says it will revise the way it curates its Trending topics section, including no longer using external websites to validate a story’s importance.
Instagram adds media buying as fourth advertising partner category.

Facebook’s general counsel responds to Congress Republicans concerned about bias with a letter; the previous week, Facebook’s legal team met with Chairman of the US Senate Commerce Committee John Thune.
Instagram adds video to carousel ads.
Facebook releases a 28-page internal document outlining guidelines for staff curating Trending Topics, in response to media reporting suggesting potential bias.
Gizmodo reveals details that Facebook's Trending Topics is actively curated by people who "suppressed" conservative news.
Twitter moves to the News category in the Apple app store.
Facebook tweaks the algorithm to focus on articles people are likely to spend time viewing.

Facebook makes several announcements at F8 that are relevant to publishers: the Live Video API will be open for publishers who want to experiment/innovate; Instant Articles is open to all publishers; publishers will be able to use messenger bots to distribute stories.
Branded content will be allowed as Facebook Instant Articles with the sponsor tagged.
Facebook allows Live Video within groups and events, live reactions from viewers, live filters, the ability to watch live with friends, a live map, and also live video in trending and search.
Twitter announces live video deal to stream NFL games, and begins pushing for live video deals with publishers.
Facebook creates option for publishers to autoplay and non-autoplay video ads in Instant; can have pre-roll video ads in any editorial video; and can have one more ad unit at the base of articles.
Snapchat Terms of Service updated to add the potential to incorporate third-party links and search results in Snapchat services.
On Facebook, publishers can see daily activity around a video.
Apple News app opens to all publishers.
Instagram announces that starting in May users’ feeds will be algorithmically driven, instead of real-time.
Facebook changes algorithm to prioritize Live Video, especially Live video that is broadcasting.
Snapchat Live Stories, beginning with the Oscars, will be viewable on the web for special occasions.
Facebook Live rolled out to all Android users.
Snapchat partners with Nielsen Digital Ad Ratings to measure, transparently, the effectiveness of ad campaigns.
Reports that Snapchat will let users subscribe to Discover channels and that it will go from logo button to magazine cover look by May.
On Instagram, publishers can now see video views and can do account switching. Instagram hits 200,000 advertisers, and 75 percent are outside of the US.
Twitter changes algorithm to make sure users see tweets they are likely to care about.
Google AMP announces solutions for subscription-supported publications, and Adobe Analytics integration.
WhatsApp increases group chat user limit to 256 people, aiming to increase enterprise appeal, including to publishers.
Snapchat launches a show called "Good Luck America" with Peter Hamby.
Facebook Live expands to all iPhone users.
Facebook reveals forthcoming "reactions" in the US, which had already been tested elsewhere in the world.
Apple plans to make subscription-only content available in the News app; publishers can only post free articles or excerpts that drive people to subscribe.
The Facebook Audience Network can be used by publishers to sell ads on their mobile sites.
Facebook opens Audience Optimization to publishers to target specific readers.
Nielsen expands Twitter TV Ratings to include Facebook conversations around TV shows, called Social Content Ratings.
Instagram publishes its first live video curation for the Golden Globes.
Digiday reports that Snapchat, up to 23 Discover partners, is rumored to be building their own ad interface API, like Facebook, to target ads to users instead of publications.
German government strikes deal with outlets that agree to delete hate speech from their sites within 24 hours, in response to increasing racism online.
Google announces AMP rollout timeline; pages will go live in February.

Facebook tweaks News Feed so it works with poor connections, like 2G. Facebook also allows publishers to sell Instant Article ad campaigns instead of having to make those ads part of their own site package, to have one ad for every 350 words of an Instant Article (up from one ad per 500 words), and to control link outs at bottom of Instant Articles.
Facebook releases Live video to the public.
Snapchat makes a Story for live/breaking news during San Bernardino.
Snapchat allows publishers to deep link back to Snapchat content from elsewhere, like other social platforms.
Snapchat launches Story Explorer, which allows users to focus on a specific moment from a story, but from additional users and perspectives.
Snapchat launches Official Stories, Stories from verified brands or influencers.
Facebook Notify, a real-time notification news app, is launched.
Instagram partner program launches; a group of 40 adtech, content marketing, and community management companies that work to help businesses on Instagram.
Instagram conducts its first video curation for Halloween.
Instagram allows businesses to use Facebook’s Ads Manager and to run campaigns across Facebook and Instagram.
Snapchat Terms of Service updated: requests right to reproduce, modify, republish, and save users’ photos, specifically in relation to Live Stories.
Google announces it has signed up over 120 news organizations for its Digital News Initiative, including the BBC, The Economist, and Der Spiegel.
Twitter announces partnerships with firms such as Spredfast, Wayin, Dataminr, ScribbleLive, and Flowics at its developer conference.
Google announces Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) project, which will allow publishers’ stories to load more quickly from search results.
Twitter Moments, curated tweets around top stories, launches.
Facebook releases 360 video. Users can move their phones for a spherical view within a video.
Facebook allows publishers to create Instant Articles in their own content management systems.
Using the Facebook ad platform technology, Instagram’s advertising platform expands globally, allows for more targeting and ad format flexibility.
Snapchat Discover expands from 12 to 15 partners. In the past, they cut old partners to add new ones so all12 fit on one screen.
Facebook Live video launches for public figures.
Snapchat axes Yahoo! and Warner Music from Discover, replaces them with BuzzFeed and iHeartRadio.
Instagram changes Explore to allow users to follow real-time news more easily by sorting by location and recency.
Google News Lab announced to support technological collaborations with journalists.
Facebook’s News Feed algorithm updated to prioritize time spent on a story above engagement.
Apple News app announced to replace the Newsstand app. Like Facebook Instant Articles, a 70/30 revenue share with publishers if Apple sells ads against their content.
Facebook releases redesigned Trending page so that when a topic is clicked a carousel appears with various stories on the topic.

Facebook announces Instant Articles, faster loading articles on Facebook for iPhone,and original launch partners. Ads are embedded in article, and there is a 70/30 revenue share with publishers if Facebook sells the ad.
Snapchat will charge advertisers 2 cents per view for ten second ads in between Discover slides (up to four slots) and during videos. This plan is called Two Pennies. It was previously 15 cents.

Facebook releases internal research on filter bubbles that finds "most people have friends who claim an opposing political ideology, and that the content in peoples’ News Feeds reflect those diverse views."
Google announces Digital News Initiative with eight European publishers.
Snapchat hires Peter Hamby from CNN and announces plans to hire more journalists for the election.
Facebook tweaks News Feed to emphasize family and friends because people are worried about "missing important updates."
Snapchat gets rid of brand stories, also known as sponsored stories, after six months.
Twitter rolls out Curator, which allows publishers to search and display tweets based on hashtags, keywords, location, and other specific details.
Twitter acquires live streaming app Periscope.
Instagram carousel ads launch.

Snapchat Discover launches. Selected publishers create a daily Discover channel, like a mini interactive magazine with an advertising revenue split arrangement where publishers can sell for 70 percent of revenue, or let Snapchat sell for 50 percent.
WhatsApp Web launches.
Facebook News Feed algorithm altered to "show fewer hoaxes."
Instagram deletes account of Australian photo and fashion agency due to a photograph with pubic hair outside bikini bottoms. (Account reactivated January 21.)
Google removes links to articles that criticized Australian organization Universal Medicine, an alleged cult.
German publishers concede defeat to Google in long-running dispute over attempt to charge license fees.
Facebook News Feed algorithm altered to reduce priority of clickbait.
Twitter blocks an account belonging to @boltai, a hacker collective that leaked internal Kremlin documents.
Facebook News Feed algorithm altered to increase priority of video.
Snapchat Our Story, a public Story aggregating many users’ activity around an event launches.
Google ordered by Canadian court to remove search results that linked to websites of Datalink, which sold technology alleged to have been stolen from a competitor.
Google launches tool that enables Europeans to request "right to be forgotten" in response to ruling by European Court of Justice.
In Russia, Twitter blocks pro-Ukrainian accounts following threats to bar the service if it did not delete tweets violating Russian law.

Launch of Facebook Newswire, powered by Storyful. While it was eventually folded, it allowed publishers to embed "newsworthy" content from Facebook into own material, use platform for newsgathering and storytelling.
Update to Google’s Terms of Service, including provision to automatically analyze content such as emails when content is sent, received, and stored.
Algorithm introduced on Instagram to tailor the "Explore"/"Popular" tab to each user.
WhatsApp bought by Facebook for $19 billion.
Facebook launches Paper, an effort at personalized news, and Trending.
Update to Google’s Terms of Service, clarifying how profile name and photo might appear in Google products.
Snapchat Stories, a compilation of "snaps" a user’s friends see, launches.
Announcement that video is coming to Instagram
After backlash, Instagram scales back earlier announcement on changing Terms of Use to allow for selling user data.
Facebook buys Instagram for $1 billion.
Fundamental rewrite of Google’s Terms of Service, adding rights for Google to "use, host, [and] store" any content submitted by users.
Facebook's internal "Abuse Standards" leaked, including policy to filter out content containing images of maps of Kurdistan and of burning Turkish flags.
Twitter begins to "curate" results on its timeline.
Snapchat, a mobile app for disappearing messages, is released.
News Corporation axes "Project Alesia," a potential competitor to Google News, over concerns about cost and readiness of proposed partners.
Google announces it will no longer adhere to Chinese censorship policies by redirecting Chinese users to its Hong Kong domain.

Links to Encyclopedia Dramatica's "Aboriginal" article removed from Google after complaint; Google defended decision on grounds that the content represented a violation of Australia's Racial Discrimination Act.
WhatsApp, a mobile messaging app company, is founded, and the app is released in May of 2009.
Facebook's Terms of Service altered to remove the automatic expiry of Facebook's license to use individuals' names, likenesses, and images if an account was deleted.
Facebook removes a photo of a mother breastfeeding babies, leading to protests.

Google’s Terms of Service unveiled, including provisions granting Google "perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide, royalty-free, and non-exclusive license to reproduce, adapt, modify, translate, publish, publicly perform, publicly display and distribute any Content which [users] submit, post or display on or through, the Services."
Facebook launches mobile site m.facebook.com.

Google delists Inquisition21, a website seeking to challenge potentially incorrect child pornography convictions in the UK. Google implies the delisting is because Inquisition21 tried to manipulate search results.
Facebook News Feed launches and displays activity from a user’s network.
Twttr (later renamed Twitter) is released. "Tweets" can only be 140 characters
Google launches Google.cn, adhering to China’s censorship policies until March 2010.
Harvard study finds 113 white nationalist, Nazi, anti-Semitic, and radical Islamic sites, and at least one fundamentalist Christian site, were removed from French and German Google listings.
